page.title: 03LANDSCAPE OF HENLLAN (1)
page.content: The block covers part of the foothills of the Denbigh Moors or Mynydd Hiraethog which are to the south west.The relief comprises an undulating surface rising from 130 m in the east to just over 200 m in the west. The smooth rolling surface is due to the erosive action of glaciers during the Pleistocene which moulded the surface giving drumlinoid summits indicating the direction of ice movement. Following the glacial action rivers have cut the surface,the most important being the Afon Meirchion which has cut a deep narrow valley along the zone of weakness of the Cefn Fault.The river flows north in the centre of the block,joined by streams from the west which have cut shallow valleys.
